title: Personal Health Information Protection Act, 2004
consolidationPeriod: From June 5, 2025 to the e-Laws currency date

sections.title: Purposes
Definitions
Health information custodian
sections.content:
A health information custodian is a person or organization described in one of the following paragraphs who has custody or control of personal health information as a result of or in connection with performing the person's or organization's powers or duties or the work described in the paragraph:

1. A health care practitioner or a person who operates a group practice of health care practitioners.
2. A service provider that operates one of the following facilities: hospitals, psychiatric facilities, independent health facilities, laboratories, ambulance services, homes for special care, community health centres, etc.
3. The evaluator designated under the Mental Health Act.
4. A community care access corporation.
5. A pharmacist, a pharmacy or an operator of a pharmacy.
6. A person who operates an out-of-hospital premises for the provision of health care to the public.

sections.title: Personal health information
Requirement for consent
sections.content:
A health information custodian shall not collect, use or disclose personal health information about an individual unless:
(a) it has the individual's consent under this Act and the collection, use or disclosure, as the case may be, is necessary for a lawful purpose; or
(b) the collection, use or disclosure, as the case may be, is permitted or required by this Act without the individual's consent.

sections.title: Permitted use
Disclosures related to providing health care
Individual's right of access
sections.content: An individual has a right of access to a record of personal health information about the individual that is in the custody or under the control of a health information custodian unless the record or the part of the record that contains the information falls within one of the exceptions under sections 52.1, 52.2 and 52.3.

sections.title: Part V.2 â€” Digital Health Identifier Activities (2025 Amendments)
sections.content:
Part V.2 was added by the 2025 amendments (c. 7, Sched. 6, s. 1-13) establishing a framework for Digital Health Identifier Activities.

Key provisions:
- s.55.15: Interpretation and definitions for digital health identifier activities
- s.55.16: Powers and duties of prescribed organization to carry out digital health identifier activities
- s.55.17: Rules for collection, use, and disclosure of personal health information for digital health identifier activities
- s.55.18: Application of Part III (consent) to digital health identifiers
- s.55.19-55.20: Administrative requirements including practices/procedures and public descriptions
- s.55.21: Protection of information held for digital health identifier purposes
- s.55.22: Disposal of inactive digital health identifiers
- s.55.23: Requirements for persons acting on the prescribed organization's behalf
- s.55.24: Breach notification requirements specific to digital health identifiers
- s.55.25: Prescribed organization's assessment obligations
- s.55.26-55.27: Ministerial directives and regulation-making powers

Therapeutic significance: Digital health identifiers create new pathways for information sharing across the healthcare system. The 2025 amendments establish safeguards that must be evaluated for both compliance and therapeutic impact on patient trust, agency, and privacy.

sections.title: Disclosures related to risks
sections.content: A health information custodian may disclose personal health information about an individual if the custodian believes on reasonable grounds that the disclosure is necessary for the purpose of eliminating or reducing a significant risk of serious bodily harm to a person or group of persons. This 'safety trumps privacy' provision represents a critical balancing point: the therapeutic value of physical safety is a precondition for all other therapeutic benefits.

sections.title: Agents and lockbox (consent directives)
sections.content:
Section 17 (Agents and information) combined with s.37(1) and s.38(1) establish the lockbox/consent directive mechanism:
- s.37(1): A client may expressly instruct that information collected with consent not be used within the organization (restricted use/lockbox)
- s.38(1): A client may expressly instruct the custodian not to disclose information to external health care providers (restricted disclosure)
- s.38(2): If a lockbox prevents disclosure of information the custodian considers necessary, the custodian must notify the receiving provider that information has been withheld

Health information custodians must PROACTIVELY determine a client's wishes about lockbox/consent directives (IPC Decision 213). Failure to do so constitutes a violation of safeguarding obligations.
